Our automated analysis identified 1,311 high-confidence duplicate payment groups totalling £2.7 million in Pendle Borough Council's published spending data — the most duplicate groups of any East Lancashire council, despite Pendle having the lowest total spend.

Why Does Pendle Have the Most Duplicates?

The answer likely lies in volume. Pendle processes 48,785 transactions — more than double Hyndburn and nearly 2.5 times Burnley. With an average transaction of just £2,604, the council handles a vast number of small payments. More payments mean more opportunities for duplication, whether in the payment system or in the data publishing process.

Detection Methodology

Every flagged duplicate matches on all four fields:

  1. Supplier name — identical after normalisation
  2. Payment amount — exact match to the penny
  3. Payment date — same day
  4. Reference number — identical transaction reference

This strict matching minimises false positives. When all four fields are identical, there should either be a clear legitimate explanation or an investigation.

The Volume Problem

Pendle's approach of processing many small transactions — 48,785 in total — creates specific risks:

  • Higher administrative cost per pound spent: Processing a £49 payment costs roughly the same as processing a £49,000 payment
  • More opportunities for error: Each transaction is a chance for a duplicate, miscoding, or overpayment
  • Harder to audit: Checking 48,785 transactions is fundamentally more difficult than checking 19,865
  • Lower visibility: Small errors are less likely to be noticed or flagged

Two Possible Explanations

As with all councils in our analysis:

  1. Data publishing errors: The council's transparency system is creating duplicate records — meaning the published data cannot be trusted
  2. Actual duplicate payments: The council is genuinely paying suppliers twice — meaning £2.7 million may have been wasted

The council should audit a sample of the flagged duplicates to determine which explanation applies — and publish the results.

All figures derived from publicly available Pendle Borough Council spending data published under the Local Government Transparency Code.
